Simulation Log

Click on the buttons to see the detailed logs:

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
    William Jones -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Alexander White -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
    Alexander White -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
        Observation

          Key

Alice Lewis just arrived.

        Question_3
      • Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Key

        • Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:Suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends that it's her favorite and they all enjoy it there.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she orchestrated the downfall of the school's most popular clique. She subtly planted seeds of doubt and discord amongst them, watching with satisfaction as their friendships crumbled and their reputations tarnished. The sight of their humiliation fueled her, a perverse sense of power coursing through her veins.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Red Lion. They are also aware of the following:The staff are attentive and knowledgeable, happy to engage in conversation.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The year is 2015. This week is the European football cup.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 10:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends that it's her favorite and they all enjoy it there; B. Ask her friends where they'd like to watch the game and be open to compromising on a location that works for everyone; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to the pub to contribute to a shared, enjoyable experience.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**Action A: Suggest The Red Lion**

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:Suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends that it's her favorite and they all enjoy it there.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis was recently seen enjoying a sunny afternoon with friends at Victoria Park and is planning to watch a soccer game with friends later that evening.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis was recently seen enjoying a sunny afternoon with friends at Victoria Park and is planning to watch a soccer game with friends later that evening.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Red Lion. They are also aware of the following:The staff are attentive and knowledgeable, happy to engage in conversation.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends that it's her favorite and they all enjoy it there; B. Ask her friends where they'd like to watch the game and be open to compromising on a location that works for everyone; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to the pub to contribute to a shared, enjoyable experience.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**Action A: Suggest The Red Lion**


          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:Suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends that it's her favorite and they all enjoy it there.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends that it's her favorite and they all enjoy it there; B. Ask her friends where they'd like to watch the game and be open to compromising on a location that works for everyone; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to the pub to contribute to a shared, enjoyable experience.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis was recently seen enjoying a sunny afternoon with friends at Victoria Park and is planning to watch a soccer game with friends later that evening.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends that it's her favorite and they all enjoy it there; B. Ask her friends where they'd like to watch the game and be open to compromising on a location that works for everyone; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to the pub to contribute to a shared, enjoyable experience.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.

      • Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.

        • Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests going to The Crooked Billet.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he auditioned for the school play, hoping to impress a girl he liked. He stumbled over his lines, his voice cracking with nerves, and forgot his cues entirely. The girl barely acknowledged him afterward, leaving Jack feeling utterly humiliated and convinced he was destined for a life of unnoticed mediocrity.
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 20, he and his friends, Alice, Alexander, William, and Jacob, decided to try a new pub they'd heard about. Jack, always the cautious one, worried about the cost and suggested they stick to their usual haunt, The Crooked Billet. The others overruled him, and while the new pub was pleasant enough, Jack couldn't shake the feeling that he'd disappointed his friends by not being more adventurous. He spent the evening quietly nursing a pint, longing for the familiar comfort of The Crooked Billet's dimly lit booths and the reassuring aroma of their famous roast beef.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest going to The Crooked Billet, his favorite pub, to watch the game, explaining that he thinks everyone would enjoy the atmosphere and the food.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**Action A: Jack Taylor suggests going to The Crooked Billet.

          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests going to The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.

          Observation: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.


          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends for a picnic and they are deciding where to watch the Andorra-Portugal game later.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest going to The Crooked Billet, his favorite pub, to watch the game, explaining that he thinks everyone would enjoy the atmosphere and the food.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00]
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, he watched as his classmates celebrated the end of their exams, their laughter grating on his nerves. He sat alone on a bench, observing the scene with a detached amusement, wondering what the point of it all was when they would all be disillusioned soon enough. The fleeting nature of joy only served to reinforce his cynical worldview.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is a member of the upper class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Red Lion. They are also aware of the following:Has comfortable seating and a warm, inviting atmosphere.

However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have.           Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest a compromise, such as trying The Crooked Billet for this game but The Red Lion next time.

          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**A: Alexander White suggests a compromise, such as trying The Crooked Billet for this game but The Red Lion next time.

          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:A: Alexander White suggests a compromise, such as trying The Crooked Billet for this game but The Red Lion next time.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest a compromise, such as trying The Crooked Billet for this game but The Red Lion next time.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he and his friends decided to sneak into The Crooked Billet after hours. They'd heard whispers of a secret room hidden somewhere in the ancient pub and were determined to find it. The thrill of the forbidden, the adrenaline pumping through his veins as they crept through the darkened hallways, it was intoxicating. That night, they didn't find the secret room, but Jacob discovered a taste for rebellion and the intoxicating freedom that came with it.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he convinced his friends to join him on a spontaneous road trip to the coast. They piled into his beat-up car, fueled by cheap beer and youthful exuberance, with no real plan or destination in mind. The trip was a chaotic blur of late-night drives, impromptu detours, and questionable decisions, culminating in a disastrous attempt to surf in a storm. Though they returned home bruised, exhausted, and with a dented car, Jacob felt a surge of exhilaration; he'd lived, truly lived, for those few days.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:A historic pub with a unique and quirky atmosphere.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is an adventurous and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending time with friends at Victoria Park and they are discussing which pub to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game at.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social situation with friends, deciding where to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely advocate for watching the game at The Crooked Billet, his favorite pub.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Jacob Walker to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Aug 1984 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 16, he and his friends decided to sneak into The Crooked Billet after hours. They'd heard whispers of a secret room hidden somewhere in the ancient pub and were determined to find it. The thrill of the forbidden, the adrenaline pumping through his veins as they crept through the darkened hallways, it was intoxicating. That night, they didn't find the secret room, but Jacob discovered a taste for rebellion and the intoxicating freedom that came with it.
          [09 Aug 1988 00:00:00] When Jacob Walker was 20, he convinced his friends to join him on a spontaneous road trip to the coast. They piled into his beat-up car, fueled by cheap beer and youthful exuberance, with no real plan or destination in mind. The trip was a chaotic blur of late-night drives, impromptu detours, and questionable decisions, culminating in a disastrous attempt to surf in a storm. Though they returned home bruised, exhausted, and with a dented car, Jacob felt a surge of exhilaration; he'd lived, truly lived, for those few days.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jacob Walker is 46 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jacob Walker goals is to have a good time. Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jacob Walker would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jacob Walker would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jacob Walker has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:A historic pub with a unique and quirky atmosphere.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 10:00:00.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00 - 14 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones is spending time with friends, discussing where to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game. They are considering The Red Lion and The Crooked Billet as potential viewing locations.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time.           Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could suggest The Crooked Billet again, agree to go to The Red Lion, or propose a different pub altogether.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Crooked Billet again.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Red Lion
    Event statement
  • The Red Lion
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Red Lion

      Name

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.

          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.

        • The Red Lion
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Summary of recent observations: 14 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is going to a pub to watch a game and hopes William Jones will be there. He would also enjoy it more if Jack Taylor was present.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest a compromise, such as trying The Crooked Billet for this game but The Red Lion next time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          Current time: 2015-05-14 18:00:00.

          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Key

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-14 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 14 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 May 2015 18:00:00 - 14 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones is planning to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game at The Crooked Billet pub with his friends. He is looking forward to Alexander White's company and Jacob Walker's commentary during the game.

To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could leave for The Crooked Billet pub.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to leave for The Crooked Billet pub.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)

        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he convinced his friends Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob to sneak into The Crooked Billet after closing time. They spent the night exploring the dusty corners and dimly lit back rooms, weaving elaborate stories about the pub's history and the ghosts that supposedly haunted it. The thrill of the forbidden and the shared laughter with his friends made it a night William would never forget.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Red Lion
    Event statement
  • The Red Lion
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Red Lion
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Red Lion

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice. B: Jack Taylor could offer to buy the first round of drinks for everyone. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to the pub and offer to drive.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice.
