        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.

They spent the night exploring the dusty corners and dimly lit back rooms, weaving elaborate stories about the pub's history and the ghosts that supposedly haunted it. The thrill of the forbidden and the shared laughter with his friends made it a night William would never forget.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest The Crooked Billet again.
          Time
        • 2015-05-14 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park.           [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White recently joined his friends for a relaxing afternoon at Victoria Park and will be watching a football game with them later.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place for the game tonight, as it was previously agreed upon.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A: Alexander White could suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place for the game tonight, as it was previously agreed upon.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:A: Alexander White could suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place for the game tonight, as it was previously agreed upon.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**A: Alexander White suggests a compromise, such as trying The Crooked Billet for this game but The Red Lion next time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could text his friends to confirm the meeting place and time for the game.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.

Alexander White just arrived.

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer

        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place for the game tonight, as it was previously agreed upon.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Red Lion. They are also aware of the following:Has comfortable seating and a warm, inviting atmosphere.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alexander White recently joined his friends for a relaxing afternoon at Victoria Park and will be watching a football game with them later.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place for the game tonight, as it was previously agreed upon.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"

      • Summary of recent observations
          Key

          Value

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          ['[15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.', '[15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we\'re meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends for a picnic. Later tonight, the group plans to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game at The Crooked Billet pub.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends for a picnic. Later tonight, the group plans to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game at The Crooked Billet pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Confirm with Alexander White that The Crooked Billet is the decided location for the game tonight; B. Suggest bringing snacks or drinks to share at The Crooked Billet to contribute to a positive group experience; C. Ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet and offer to drive.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Confirm with Alexander White that The Crooked Billet is the decided location for the game tonight;


          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:Confirm with Alexander White that The Crooked Billet is the decided location for the game tonight.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends that it's her favorite and they all enjoy it there; B. Ask her friends where they'd like to watch the game and be open to compromising on a location that works for everyone; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to the pub to contribute to a shared, enjoyable experience.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:Suggest The Red Lion as the pub to watch the game, reminding her friends that it's her favorite and they all enjoy it there.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:Suggest The Crooked Billet as a compromise, acknowledging that while it's not her first choice, she's open to trying new places.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Suggest The Crooked Billet as a compromise, acknowledging that while it's not her first choice, she's open to trying new places.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Crooked Billet as a compromise, acknowledging that while it's not her first choice, she's open to trying new places; B. Ask Jacob Walker directly if he's planning on going to the pub and express her enthusiasm about watching the game with him; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to The Crooked Billet to contribute to a positive shared experience.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis just arrived at Victoria Park to join friends for a picnic. Later tonight, the group plans to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game at The Crooked Billet pub.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Confirm with Alexander White that The Crooked Billet is the decided location for the game tonight; B. Suggest bringing snacks or drinks to share at The Crooked Billet to contribute to a positive group experience; C. Ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet and offer to drive.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and adventurous person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be excited to meet up with his friends and enjoy the game at The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and adventurous person who enjoys spending time with his friends.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is experiencing low-level pain and is planning to watch a soccer game with friends at The Crooked Billet pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a relaxed and social situation, preparing to meet his friends at a pub to watch a football game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to the game and enjoying the company of his friends.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely advocate for watching the game at The Crooked Billet, his favorite pub.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"

    • Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"

      • Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.

        • Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest going to The Crooked Billet, his favorite pub, to watch the game, explaining that he thinks everyone would enjoy the atmosphere and the food.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests going to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:**Action A: Jack Taylor suggests going to The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice. B: Jack Taylor could offer to buy the first round of drinks for everyone. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to the pub and offer to drive.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at The Crooked Billet. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet and offer to drive.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game.
          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are lounging and will be meeting later at The Crooked Billet to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice. B: Jack Taylor could offer to buy the first round of drinks for everyone. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to the pub and offer to drive.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at The Crooked Billet. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet and offer to drive.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at The Crooked Billet. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet and offer to drive.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor just arrived at Victoria Park where friends are lounging and will be meeting later at The Crooked Billet to watch the Luxembourg vs. Israel game.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at The Crooked Billet. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet and offer to drive.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Sounds good to me.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Sounds good to me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey everyone, since we're talking about the game tonight, how about we head to The Red Lion? It's my favorite and I know you guys enjoy it there too.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
      Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
      Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
      Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.
      Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Sounds good to me.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, while The Red Lion is great, how about we try The Crooked Billet tonight? It's got a really good atmosphere and they make fantastic nachos.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey, how about we try The Crooked Billet this time, and then The Red Lion next time? That way, we can all get what we want.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"
          Current time: 2015-05-15 10:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with his friends, especially watching games at The Crooked Billet. He values Jacob Walker's company and appreciates a lively atmosphere.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones can go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game with his friends.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Crooked Billet.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
