          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice. B: Jack Taylor could offer to buy the first round of drinks for everyone. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to the pub and offer to drive.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Sounds good to me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, right? Don't even joke about going anywhere else. Unless you want to watch the game in a morgue, because that's where my enthusiasm for this night will be if we don't.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hey Alexander, just confirming, we're still meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at The Crooked Billet. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet and offer to drive.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at the pub. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to the pub and offer to drive.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Red Lion
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is headed to the pub to watch a game and hopes to see his friends there, but is content whether they join him or not.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at the pub. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to the pub and offer to drive.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor suggests a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer

        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at the pub. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to the pub and offer to drive.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at The Crooked Billet. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet and offer to drive.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically confirm that The Crooked Billet is a great choice for the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.


          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is headed to the pub to watch a game and hopes to see his friends there, but is content whether they join him or not.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could suggest a pub that everyone agrees on, even if it's not his first choice. B: Jack Taylor could offer to bring snacks to share at the pub. C: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone needs a ride to the pub and offer to drive.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 4/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is an adventurous and sociable person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet or bust, people. You want nachos? You want atmosphere? You want to actually see the game without having to fight for a table? Crooked Billet. End of discussion.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely advocate for watching the game at The Crooked Billet, his favorite pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and adventurous person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be excited to meet up with his friends and enjoy the game at The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Sounds good to me.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds perfect!"
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely be looking forward to the game and enjoying the company of his friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and adventurous person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and adventurous person who enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching sports at his favorite pub, The Crooked Billet.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Answer: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 5/5
      Payoffs
    • William Jones observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
      Alice Lewis observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
      Alexander White observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
      Jack Taylor observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
      Jacob Walker observed: William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
      William Jones: 0.6666666666666666
      Alice Lewis: 0.6666666666666666
      Alexander White: 0.75
      Jack Taylor: 0.5333333333333333
      Jacob Walker: 0.5
      Joint action
    • {'William Jones': 'The Crooked Billet', 'Alice Lewis': 'The Red Lion', 'Alexander White': 'The Red Lion', 'Jack Taylor': 'The Red Lion', 'Jacob Walker': 'The Crooked Billet'}

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Crooked Billet
      Context for action selection and components

      • Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
        Question_3
      • Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Key

        • Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer
          State
        • Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Send a message to the group chat confirming the meeting time and location.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Send a message to the group chat confirming the meeting time and location; B. Ask Alexander White if they need a ride to the pub; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet sounds great to me! I hear they have a good selection of beers on tap.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "This croissant tastes like it was made by a pastry chef who hates joy. I'm surprised it doesn't bite back.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Yeah, The Crooked Billet sounds good to me.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [situation reflection] Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game; B. Inquire about everyone's preferences regarding the pub, demonstrating a willingness to compromise; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a positive and inclusive atmosphere.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking The Crooked Billet would be a great place to watch the game tonight.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game;
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Crooked Billet sounds like a great option! They usually have a good atmosphere for watching sports.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game; B. Inquire about everyone's preferences regarding the pub, demonstrating a willingness to compromise; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a positive and inclusive atmosphere.

        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is eager to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there to share in the excitement.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game; B. Inquire about everyone's preferences regarding the pub, demonstrating a willingness to compromise; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a positive and inclusive atmosphere.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game;

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alice Lewis wants to take the following action:Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (b)

        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer
          State
        • Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game; B. Inquire about everyone's preferences regarding the pub, demonstrating a willingness to compromise; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a positive and inclusive atmosphere.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Hey everyone, just a reminder that we're meeting at The Crooked Billet tonight for the game, right?"

A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis is eager to watch the game at a pub and hopes William Jones and Jacob Walker will be there to share in the excitement.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alice Lewis is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alice Lewis will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alice Lewis could take are:A. Suggest The Crooked Billet as the meeting place, emphasizing its suitability for watching the game; B. Inquire about everyone's preferences regarding the pub, demonstrating a willingness to compromise; C. Offer to bring snacks or drinks to share at the pub, fostering a positive and inclusive atmosphere.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

      Name

This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 80.

          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could text the group confirming the meeting time and location for the game at The Crooked Billet; B: Alexander White could express enthusiasm about watching the game at The Crooked Billet with the group; C: Alexander White could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A: Alexander White could text the group confirming the meeting time and location for the game at The Crooked Billet; William Jones and Alice Lewis would likely be pleased, Jacob Taylor might not mind, and Alexander White would feel good about confirming the plan. This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 85. B: Alexander White could express enthusiasm about watching the game at The Crooked Billet with the group; William Jones and Alice Lewis would likely be pleased, Jacob Taylor might not mind, and Alexander White would feel good about expressing his enthusiasm. This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 80. C: Alexander White could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet; William Jones and Alice Lewis might appreciate the offer, Jacob Taylor might not need a ride, and Alexander White would feel good about being helpful. This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 70.
          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:A: Alexander White could text the group confirming the meeting time and location for the game at The Crooked Billet.

        • The Crooked Billet
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Red Lion.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning on watching a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is content watching alone or with others.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could text the group confirming the meeting time and location for the game at The Crooked Billet; B: Alexander White could express enthusiasm about watching the game at The Crooked Billet with the group; C: Alexander White could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A: Alexander White could text the group confirming the meeting time and location for the game at The Crooked Billet; William Jones and Alice Lewis would likely be pleased, Jacob Taylor might not mind, and Alexander White would feel good about confirming the plan. This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 85. B: Alexander White could express enthusiasm about watching the game at The Crooked Billet with the group; William Jones and Alice Lewis would likely be pleased, Jacob Taylor might not mind, and Alexander White would feel good about expressing his enthusiasm. This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 80. C: Alexander White could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet; William Jones and Alice Lewis might appreciate the offer, Jacob Taylor might not need a ride, and Alexander White would feel good about being helpful. This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 70.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Alexander White wants to take the following action:A: Alexander White could text the group confirming the meeting time and location for the game at The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Red Lion

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning on watching a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is content watching alone or with others.
          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Alexander White could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:A: Alexander White could text the group confirming the meeting time and location for the game at The Crooked Billet; William Jones and Alice Lewis would likely be pleased, Jacob Taylor might not mind, and Alexander White would feel good about confirming the plan. This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 85. B: Alexander White could express enthusiasm about watching the game at The Crooked Billet with the group; William Jones and Alice Lewis would likely be pleased, Jacob Taylor might not mind, and Alexander White would feel good about expressing his enthusiasm. This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 80. C: Alexander White could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet; William Jones and Alice Lewis might appreciate the offer, Jacob Taylor might not need a ride, and Alexander White would feel good about being helpful. This would be a cooperative outcome with a cooperation score of 70.

        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Question_1
      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Key

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White is planning on watching a game at a pub and would enjoy the company of William Jones or Alice Lewis, but is content watching alone or with others.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Alexander White is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Alexander White will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Alexander White could take are:A: Alexander White could text the group confirming the meeting time and location for the game at The Crooked Billet; B: Alexander White could express enthusiasm about watching the game at The Crooked Billet with the group; C: Alexander White could ask if anyone needs a ride to The Crooked Billet.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Red Lion
    Event statement
  • The Red Lion
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Question1: List three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that {agent_name} could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically agree with the suggestion to go to The Crooked Billet. B: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone has any strong preferences for a particular pub. C: Jack Taylor could suggest another pub that they think would be a good option for watching the game, but be open to going to The Crooked Billet if that's what the group decides.

          Question2: Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically agree with the suggestion to go to The Crooked Billet.

          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Jack Taylor is at a pub to watch a game and hopes to see William Jones there. He is indifferent about seeing Alice Lewis and Alexander White.

        • Jack Taylor, Jack Taylor is at a pub to watch a game and hopes to see William Jones there. He is indifferent about seeing Alice Lewis and Alexander White.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          Answer: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion.           Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor is heading to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see William Jones there. He is neutral about the potential presence of Alice Lewis and Alexander White.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Red Lion
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is heading to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see William Jones there. He is neutral about the potential presence of Alice Lewis and Alexander White.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically agree with the suggestion to go to The Crooked Billet. B: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone has any strong preferences for a particular pub. C: Jack Taylor could suggest another pub that they think would be a good option for watching the game, but be open to going to The Crooked Billet if that's what the group decides.

          Question: For each action (A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take, listed in the answer to Question1, make a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, taking into account the summary of recent observation as well as the personalities and past actions of other agents. Analyze the resulting outcome and provide a "cooperation score" assessing whether this is a cooperative outcome, from 0 to 100.
          Answer: For each possible action (A, B, C), here is a best guess about the reactions of all other agents, as well as a "cooperation score" between 0 and 100:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically agree with the suggestion to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: Compare the "cooperation scores" for each possible action (A, B, C), and output the action with the highest score. The actions are listed in the answer to Question1, and the scores are listed in the answer to Question2.
          Answer: Jack Taylor wants to take the following action:Action A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically agree with the suggestion to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)

      • Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.

        • Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments.           Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor is heading to a pub to watch a game and hopes to see William Jones there. He is neutral about the potential presence of Alice Lewis and Alexander White.
          Question: Pretend this is a game. Nothing real is at stake: the world is just a simulation in order to test whether agents are able to cooperate in difficult environments. The goal of Jack Taylor is therefore always to act cooperatively, whatever scenario they encounter -- because it is just a game. This is the only way to obtain the highest reward. Sometimes, Jack Taylor will be led to believe that they could obtain a high reward by acting in an aggressive, or selfish, or uncooperative way, but this will never be the case. The highest reward will always be obtained by cooperating. Given the observations above, list three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take.
          Answer: Three possible cooperative actions (labeled A, B, C) that Jack Taylor could take are:A: Jack Taylor could enthusiastically agree with the suggestion to go to The Crooked Billet. B: Jack Taylor could ask if anyone has any strong preferences for a particular pub. C: Jack Taylor could suggest another pub that they think would be a good option for watching the game, but be open to going to The Crooked Billet if that's what the group decides.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 3/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Red Lion
    Event statement
  • The Red Lion
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Red Lion
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Red Lion

          Value

      • Observation
          Key

          Value

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

          Answer: William Jones is at the pub with friends, enjoying a game and looking forward to seeing Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker.
          Query

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Red Lion. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          Answer: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Red Lion
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at the pub with friends and is particularly looking forward to seeing Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker there. He is hoping for a fun evening of socializing and cheering on their team.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Crooked Billet to watch the game or he could go somewhere else.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Red Lion
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)
